results.title: Mountain farmers: Switzerland
results.creator_credit: John Ferno and Louis de Rochemont Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Earth and it’s peoples”.
This film describes the life and characteristics of the mountain valleys of Switzerland, including the Emmenthal (German), the Engadine (Italian), and western Switzerland (French). All available land is used , being divided for the most part into small holdings of approximately fifteen acres. Water power is a natural resource, providing electricity. Crops vary in each region, as do habits and customs. Co-operatives flourish. We are shown the farm and family life of farmer Hofer, a typical farmer of the region, including glimpses of work and play, in summer and winter; the daily lives of these mountain farmers.

results.title: The Lumber states (USA - the Pacific Northwest)
results.creator_credit: Louis de Rochemont Associates and United World Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Earth and it’s peoples”.
A survey of the lumbering industry of the North Western States of USA. Draws attention to the careful planning necessary for the best use of the forests; seed blocks and logging areas must be organised and new forests started to maintain the timber crop; also timber felling must be regulated to prevent waste and destruction. Describes how other natural resources add to the productivity of these states.

results.title: Living in a metropolis: Greater New York
results.creator_credit: Louis De Rochemont and Louis de Rochemont Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Earth and it’s peoples”.
This film describes New York City; population 9,000,000 (1949). Aerial views of the city and harbour, its office buildings etc show briefly its general appearance. A gateway to the United States from the East, it is a terminus for shipping, a railroad centre and has three airports. Film also includes glimpses of Park Avenue, Harlem, Chinatown, the housing projects, subways, bridges, tunnels, the food markets, restaurants, the banks on Wall Street, the garment industry and departmental stores, Central Park, Coney Island and Times Square.

results.title: Land behind the dikes: the Netherlands
results.creator_credit: John Ferno and Louis de Rochemont Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Earth and it’s peoples”.
Makes the point that the Netherlands, with about one-half of the land area below sea level, is largely man-made. Illustrates draining, reclamation, farming, the use of canals for transport, and the richness of the polders.

results.title: An Island nation: Japan
results.creator_credit: Victor Jurgens and Louis de Rochemont Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Earth and it’s peoples”.
Life in urban and rural Japan, showing the customs and work of a Japanese farm family as observed by their young cousin from the city. Shows how this country of 80,000,000 people, handicapped by mountainous terrain and without the necessary raw materials for industrial development, has done to overcome her difficulties. Japan’s industry is based on the importation of raw materials and the selling of finished products throughout the world, made possible by low wages and long hours of work. In rural areas, people work long and hard to gain a livelihood from the soil.

results.title: An Industrial lake port
results.creator_credit: Victor Vicas and Louis de Rochemont Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Earth and it’s peoples”.
The film opens in a lighthouse on the Great Lakes where a sailor from the United States Coast Guard is entertaining a grup of visiting Sea Scouts on a tour of the region. Discusses the various industries that take place on the Great Lakes and how in winter when the lakes freeze over, the crews on the cargo ships must work on ocean-going vessels for part of the year when the lakes are not navigable.

results.title: Horsemen of the Pampa (Argentina)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Earth and it’s peoples”.
Life in Argentina. The story centres around a gaucho and his son, who are seen in typical surroundings carrying out their daily activities and enjoying home life at night

results.title: Highlands of the Andes
results.creator_credit: Jules Bucher, Louis de Rochemont Associates and United World Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Earth and it’s peoples”.
A description of the Andes of Peru and the mineral resources of the area. Shows the people working in the gold, silver and copper mines, also farmers cultivating the poor, rocky soil.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jules Bucher, Louis de Rochemont Associates and United World Films

results.title: French Canadians: the St Lawrence Lowland, Quebec
results.creator_credit: J.H. Lenauer and Louis de Rochemont Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Earth and it’s peoples”.
Looks at life in the village of St Pierre in Quebec, depicting farming and dairying activities which have undergone little change for over three generations.

results.title: Food for Paris markets
results.creator_credit: John Ferno and Louis de Rochemont Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Earth and it’s peoples”.
This film shows the sources of food from the sea and earth which supply the Paris markets, and stresses the human co-operation and continuity of effort necessary to maintain them. From the coastal towns along the rocky shores of Brittany came a variety of sea foods. from a day’s catch, some of the fish is sold to markets and some to local canneries. From Normandy, come vegetables, grains and fruits. Wines are another of France’s famed products especially champagne from the region around Rheims. Method of producing and distributing the wine is also featured.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Ferno and Louis de Rochemont Associates
